title: Using large language models for extracting stressful life events to assess their impact on preventive colon cancer screening adherence

Scherbakov et al. BMC Public Health           (2025) 25:12 
https://doi.org/10.1186/s12889-024-21123-2
BMC Public Health
*Correspondence:
Jihad S. Obeid
jobeid@musc.edu
Full list of author information is available at the end of the article
Abstract
Background Increase in early onset colorectal cancer makes adherence to screening a significant public health 
concern, with various social determinants playing a crucial role in its incidence, diagnosis, treatment, and outcomes. 
Stressful life events, such as divorce, marriage, or sudden loss of job, have a unique position among the social 
determinants of health.
Methods We applied a large language model (LLM) to social history sections of clinical notes in the health records 
database of the Medical University of South Carolina to extract recent stressful life events and assess their impact on 
colorectal cancer screening adherence. We used pattern-matching regular expressions to detect a possible signal 
in social histories and ran LLM four times on each social history to achieve self-consistency and then used logistic 
regression to estimate the impact of life events on the probability of having a code in health records related to 
colorectal cancer screening.
Results The LLM detected 380 patients with one or more stressful life events and 5,344 patients with no life events. 
The events with the most negative impact on screening were arrest or incarceration (OR 0.26 95% CI 0.06–0.77), 
becoming homeless (OR 0.18 95% CI 0.01–0.92), separation from spouse or partner (OR 0.32 95% CI 0.05–1.18), 
getting married or starting to live with a partner (OR 0.60 95% CI 0.19–1.53). Death of somebody close to the patient 
(excluding their spouse) increased the chance of screening (OR 1.21 95% CI 0.71–2.05). Many of the observed effects 
did not reach statistical significance.
Conclusion Our findings suggest that stressful life events might have a counterintuitive impact on screening, with 
some events, such as bereavement, were associated with increased screening. Future work should be focused on 
validating the research findings using data from other health institutions. In addition, expanding the list of stressful 
life events by including a validated scale of stressful life events for patients from historically marginalized groups is 
warranted.
Using large language models for extracting 
stressful life events to assess their impact 
on preventive colon cancer screening 
adherence
Dmitry Scherbakov1, Paul M. Heider1, Ramsey Wehbe1,3, Alexander V. Alekseyenko1, Leslie A. Lenert1 and Jihad 
S. Obeid1,2*
Page 2 of 10
Scherbakov et al. BMC Public Health            (2025) 25:12 
Background
Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a significant public health 
concern, with various social determinants playing a cru -
cial role in its incidence, diagnosis, treatment, and out -
comes. Recent recognition of the increase in early onset 
CRC makes improving screening follow-through an 
important public health concern [ 1]. As with screening 
for other diseases, adherence to CRC screening recom -
mendations is crucial for early detection and prevention 
of the disease [ 2]. Research has shown that social and 
demographic factors such as education, age, income, and 
healthcare access influence the utilization of CRC screen-
ing tests [3].
Stressful life events, such as divorce, marriage, or sud -
den loss of job, have a unique role as additional social 
determinants of health [ 4] as they span all aspects of life 
and may occur regardless of a patient’s social and eco -
nomic status. However, populations with lower socioeco-
nomic status are more vulnerable to adverse life events 
[5]. Negative stressful events in the social and family net -
works, such as the loss of a friend or family member, are 
some of the most stressful and difficult for individuals to 
adapt to and have the highest impact on health and well-
being [6].
Socioeconomic stress-related neighborhood factors 
have been shown to affect physiological stress and ele -
vated allostatic load, which in turn impacts health dis -
parities [ 7]. However, the impact of stressful life events 
on adherence to cancer screening remains elusive. Davis 
et al. show that patients with anxiety, a disorder related 
to life stressors, are 1.7 more likely to miss mammo -
gram screenings [ 8]. Similarly, psychological distress has 
been found to negatively impact prostate cancer screen -
ing among U.S. military veterans, underscoring the role 
of psychological factors in preventive health behaviors 
[9]. On the other hand, some events considered stress -
ful, such as getting married or raising children [ 10], may 
form new social connections that alter health behaviors 
in a positive way [ 11]. Research on breast cancer adher -
ence shows that supportive social networks can encour -
age cancer screening [ 12]. Thus, stressful life events, 
from the perspective of the health belief model [ 13], can 
act as both facilitators of screening (e.g., when they form 
new social connections, such as in the case of marriage 
or childbirth) or as barriers (e.g., when they negatively 
impact mental health or when social connections break 
down).
Furthermore, life events, such as getting married, have 
differential effects depending on a set of individual cir -
cumstances and personality factors [ 14]. Marriage has 
been long considered a positive factor in well-being and 
preventive health behavior [15]. While the literature gen-
erally supports the notion that marriage is associated 
with improved well-being, research has shown that mari -
tal satisfaction can vary between spouses, with husbands’ 
satisfaction often being more dependent on the specific 
content of the relationship, while wives’ satisfaction is 
influenced by both the quality of the marriage and their 
overall well-being [16].
There is also significant variability in life events com -
monly perceived as negative or adverse. Research indi -
cates that divorce or widowhood can lead to negative 
physical health consequences, with these effects intensi -
fying with age [ 17]. Other studies have shown, however, 
that various individuals respond to divorce differently, 
and negative outcomes may not be pronounced for some 
people [ 18]. Additionally, entering a new marriage post-
divorce has been associated with improvements in men -
tal health [19].
The research on life events and health outcomes is 
impeded by the lack of systematic representation in elec -
tronic health records (EHR) [ 4]. Natural Language Pro -
cessing (NLP) emerged as a valuable tool in healthcare 
for extracting information from clinical notes. Clinical 
notes contain unstructured data that can provide insights 
into patients’ social history, including details on mood, 
medication, lifestyle patterns, and social determinants of 
health [ 20–22]. By automating the extraction of clinical 
features, NLP reduces the reliance on manual abstrac -
tion, enhances the accuracy of data extraction, and 
enables the conversion of unstructured data into struc -
tured formats for analysis [21, 23, 24].
Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs), 
as a subdomain of NLP have shown promise in revolu -
tionizing healthcare, with tasks ranging from analyzing 
biomedical data [25] to extraction of social determinants 
of health [ 26, 27]. These technologies, such as ChatGPT, 
offer opportunities to analyze vast amounts of data effi -
ciently and identify patterns related to social determi -
nants that influence health outcomes [ 26, 28]. LLMs 
provide contextual understanding, temporal reasoning, 
and adaptability to complex free-text data compared to 
rigid pattern-matching or other approaches, such as bag-
of-words [ 29–31]. By leveraging these tools, researchers 
can better understand the complex interplay between 
social factors and health, leading to more targeted inter -
ventions and improved patient care.
In this project, we aimed to assess the impact of stress -
ful life events on CRC screening adherence using the 
logistic regression model and LLM to extract stressful 
Keywords Colorectal cancer, Screening adherence, Stressful life events, Social determinants of health, Large 
Language models, Electronic health records, Natural language processing
Page 3 of 10
Scherbakov et al. BMC Public Health            (2025) 25:12 
events from the social history sections of clinical notes 
for patients at the Medical University of South Carolina 
(MUSC).
Methods
The study is a retrospective chart review using longitu -
dinal EHR data. For screened patients, the baseline time 
is the screening date minus 5 years. The 5-year period 
was selected because events that happened prior to the 
5-year cut-off were considered not to have a substan -
tial effect on screening decisions. For patients who were 
never screened, the baseline time is the “expected screen-
ing date” (calculated as the time from their first visit 
plus the average time to screening from the first visit for 
screened patients) minus 5 years. This process is further 
described in the Description of the dataset used for analy-
sis subsection.
Patient phenotyping using EHR data
We extracted information from the EHR in Epic (Epic 
Systems Corporation, Verona WI) on all patients in the 
MUSC Health network aged 40 + and their respective 
clinical notes, diagnoses, and procedural data spanning 
2012 through 2022. Forty years was selected as a cut-off  
age, following recommendations by the US Multi-Society 
Task Force, which recommends screening at age 45 years 
for average-risk patients and screening at age 40 years in 
persons with a family history of CRC [32].
To ensure active patients in this sample, we subset 
patients who had:
  • At least 2 codes (procedural or diagnostic) within 3 
years of each other.
  • At least one clinical note with the social history 
section (social history section was detected 
and extracted from clinical notes using regular 
expressions, two examples of social history section 
can be found in Supplement A).
The patients were marked as screened for CRC if they 
had one of the following codes:
  • General screening code (ICD-10-CM Z12.11).
  • Colonoscopy (CPT 45378, CPT 45379, CPT 45380, 
CPT 45381, CPT 45385, CPT 1022231, HCPCS 
G0121, HCPCS G0120, HCPCS G0105).
  • Sigmoidoscopy (CPT 1007635, HCPCS G0104).
  • Occult blood test (CPT 82270, CPT 82274, CPT 
82272, HCPCS G0328).
  • DNA test (CPT 81528, LOINC 77354-9).
  • CRC-related surgeries (ICD-10-PCS codes 
0DBN8ZX, 0DBH8ZX, 0DBE8ZX, 0DBN4ZX, 
0DBH4ZX, 0D9E8ZX, 0DBH7ZX, 0DBE7ZX, 
0D9H3ZX, 0D9H4ZX).
This approach to phenotyping screened patients was 
adopted from the Centers for Disease Control and Pre -
vention PLACES project categories [ 33], with a few 
added surgical codes and the general screening code. In 
addition, we removed the time window consideration for 
certain cases. For example, colonoscopy screening is con-
sidered up to date if completed within 10 years. Keeping 
this standard in mind along with the limitation that our 
data spans a 10 year study period, we removed all tempo -
ral considerations and marked the patient as screened if 
they had one of the codes listed above.
Patient was excluded from the subsample if they had:
  • Malignant neoplasm of colon (ICD-10-CM C18).
  • Malignant neoplasm of sigmoid colon (ICD-10-CM 
C18.7).
  • Malignant neoplasm of ascending colon (ICD-
10-CM C18.2).
  • Malignant neoplasm of descending colon (ICD-
10-CM C18.6).
  • Malignant neoplasm of transverse colon (ICD-
10-CM C18.4).
Notes processing and LLM inference
Since annotating all social histories with LLM was not 
feasible at our institution due to computational consider-
ations and time limitations, we initially applied pattern-
matching regular expressions to detect a possible signal 
in social histories. For example, notes containing words 
like “evicted, ” “eviction, ” and “recently divorced” are likely 
to contain a stressful life event. A list of search terms 
was created by using the list of stressful life events and 
iteratively applying the whole script to the notes to avoid 
having a large number of false positives (for example, the 
terms “married” and “divorced” were excluded, because 
many notes contained marital status, e.g. “Pt is married” , 
while we were looking for changes in marital status, such 
as “recently married”).
Only patients with notes containing these types of pos -
sible signal were selected for further processing. A pat -
tern-matching R script can be found in the supplement 
A.
We then created a few-shot learning LLM template for 
extracting stressful life events.
from social histories in clinical notes with the Mixtral 
8 × 7B model [34]. This model provides high performance 
compared to similar-sized alternative models, according 
to independent benchmarks, such as Hugging Face, and 
this model quantized to 4 bits was the largest model that 
was feasible to run on-premises with existing resources 
in a secure computing environment (since we had sensi -
tive data in the notes that contains Personally Identifiable 
Information, using cloud LLMs like OpenAI was not an 
option). The prompt included the range of stressful life 
Page 4 of 10
Scherbakov et al. BMC Public Health            (2025) 25:12 
events from the Holmes and Rahe scale [ 35]. This scale 
is one of the most widely used scales for assessing stress -
ful life events [6]; however, it lacks specific events impor -
tant for historically marginalized groups. To mitigate this 
issue, we added some examples of these events identi -
fied during our recent scoping review [ 4]. The LLM had 
to extract stressful life event and one of the three tem -
poral aspects of the event: (1) the year when the event 
happened, or (2) An indication that it happened recently, 
or (3) An indication that the year or recency of the event 
could not be determined. We included a few stress -
ful events deemed positive (or at least positive for most 
people), such as getting married or starting to date. The 
events were presented in the prompt in random order. 
This prompt was developed iteratively by testing on a 
subset of 50 notes. The full prompt with few-shot exam -
ples can be found in Supplement B.
We ran the LLM inference 4 times on each social his -
tory to achieve self-consistency. The value 4 was chosen 
to balance between accuracy and computation time on 
our hardware [ 36]. Each run is independent (doesn’t use 
information from prior runs) and may produce unique 
results due to the indeterministic nature of LLM infer -
ence when a temperature parameter is set to a non-zero 
value (we used a value of 0.7) [ 37]. Thus, each additional 
run ensures better confidence in the extracted events, as 
results are aggregated: we assign the final result if it was 
confirmed in at least 2 across all 4 runs. For example, in 
the following 4 inferences of a single social history note, 
the algorithm picks only the label “married” with a year 
of event 2021 since the date for “arrest” couldn’t be suc -
cessfully determined in at least two runs:
 
Run (1) Married (2021).
Run (2) Arrest (2018), Married (2021).
Run (3) No events detected.
Run (4) Arrest (recent event).
The diagram depicting the steps of note processing and 
inference is presented in Supplement C. Figure 2.
Description of the dataset used for analysis
The resulting dataset was converted to a wide format 
with the number of rows equal to the number of patients, 
binary columns corresponding to stressful life events 
detected in the notes, columns corresponding to time 
indication of when each event happened (could be one of 
4-digit year when the event happened, 4-digit year corre -
sponding to the year of note for recent events, “no date”) 
and whether the corresponding patient was screened 
positive or negative, along with the screening date. If 
the event happened more than 5 years before the date of 
screening or if the event happened after the screening, it 
was excluded from analysis as it was considered not to 
have an impact on screening.
Since we excluded events for screened patients (as 
described above), we had to account for possible imbal -
ance for unscreened patients as they would have a lon -
ger tail of events than the screened patients would have. 
To equalize the potential imbalance, we first calculated 
the meantime interval for screened patients from their 
first visit to their screening. We then excluded events for 
unscreened patients that occurred after this mean time 
interval and all events 5 years prior to their first visit.
Each row in the dataset also contained demographic 
information like age, race, and gender. This dataset was 
used in a logistic regression model, which allows for easy 
interpretation of odds ratios [ 38], where screened status 
was a binary dependent variable (ever screened/never 
screened), and binary variables (event occurred/event 
not occurred) corresponding to the occurrence of each 
type of stressful life event, along with age, race, and gen -
der were independent variables.
Manual review of notes
All notes with stressful events detected by LLM and an 
additional 50 notes with no events detected were manu -
ally reviewed to assess precision and recall of extraction 
and to ensure that only correct events are used in logis -
tic regression analysis. The review was performed by a 
single human reviewer (DS) who was using a guideline 
validated by other team members to ensure consistent 
review. The guideline was based on the prompt that the 
LLM used but included more examples. For instance, 
the event “experienced abuse as a child or lived in prob -
lematic household” was elaborated by providing specific 
cases (drug/alcohol usage in the household, violence 
between guardians, verbal abuse, sexual abuse, physical 
abuse).
In addition, the precision of extraction of date of event 
was evaluated on a subset of 100 notes. Events affecting a 
small number of patients ( < 10) were excluded from the 
population table and odds ratio analysis.
Results
Of the initial sample of 777,962 patients, only 109,556 
had at least 2 visits more than 3 years apart and at least 
one note with social history. These patients had 375,334 
notes with social history sections. After we applied pat -
tern matching, 23,894 social histories were preselected 
for LLM processing.
After 4 applications of the LLM on each social history, 
we deleted events outside of the screening interval. The 
mean time interval from the first visit to the screening 
was 4 years. This time interval was used on unscreened 
patients to similarly exclude events beyond the aver -
age time interval horizon to better balance screened 
and unscreened patients, as described in the Methods 
section.
Page 5 of 10
Scherbakov et al. BMC Public Health            (2025) 25:12 
Manual verification of the events reduced the total 
number of correctly extracted events to 701 (Table  1). 
Precision of extraction of the event’s date (temporal fac -
tor) was 87.7%. When considering unique events per 
patient, this rate translates to 380 patients with one or 
more events and 5,344 patients with no events (Table 2).
The effect of stressful life events and selected demo -
graphic variables on cancer screening adherence was 
evaluated using a logistic regression model. The odds 
ratios of being screened, sorted by the lowest p-value 
first are presented in Fig.  1. The regression table can be 
found in Supplement D (Table 3). Being White or Cauca-
sian race reduces the odds of screening (OR 0.64 95% CI 
0.57–0.73), along with belonging to other races (OR 0.76 
95% CI 0.54–1.05). Age had a positive impact on screen -
ing with each additional year in age increasing the proba-
bility of screening slightly (OR 1.01 95% CI 1-1.01). Males 
had lower screening rates in our cohort (OR 0.82 95% CI 
0.73–0.91). The life events with the most negative impact 
were arrest or incarceration (OR 0.26 95% CI 0.06–0.77), 
becoming homeless (OR 0.18 95% CI 0.01–0.92), separa -
tion from spouse or partner (OR 0.32 95% CI 0.05–1.18), 
married or starting to live with a partner (OR 0.6 95% CI 
0.19–1.53), although latter events had relatively low sta -
tistical significance due to a small number of detected 
events. Death of somebody close to the patient (exclud -
ing spouse) increased the chance of screening, although 
the effect was not statistically significant (OR 1.21 95% 
CI 0.71–2.05). Other events, such as divorce, death of 
spouse, and critical illness did not appear to have effect 
on screening adherence.
Discussion
Adherence to cancer screening guidelines among cancer 
survivors is essential for early detection and improved 
outcomes [ 39]. In this project, we demonstrated that 
stressful life events may negatively impact adherence to 
screening.
We were expecting that marriage, along with starting 
to date, would be correlated with screening theoretically 
through increased social support. For example, one study 
has found that suggestion of a friend or a family mem -
ber was important in the decision to get screened [ 40]. 
However, in our sample, marriage also had a negative,

Page 7 of 10
Scherbakov et al. BMC Public Health            (2025) 25:12 
although statistically insignificant, impact. That may 
be explained by the fact that our data included an older 
cohort. Hobson et al. have observed that marriage is get -
ting more stressful for older adults [6].
In line with other studies, we have found that incar -
ceration is a significant barrier to CRC screening [ 41]. In 
our study, we were able to show that not only currently 
detained but also patients with a history of incarceration 
had, indeed, much lower screening rates. This prompts 
for targeted interventions for this vulnerable population.
Losing access to financial resources due to unexpected 
job loss or becoming homeless expectedly reduced the 
chances of screening. Indeed, studies show that neigh -
borhoods with lower socioeconomic status have lower 
screening rates [42]. Unfortunately, many providers often 
do not have any knowledge of whether the patient they 
see is suffering from any such economic hardships. The 
event of becoming unemployed, which demonstrated a 
positive impact on screening, suggests that a consider -
able share of these events is related to retirement. This 
can explain the increased screening rates, as older pop -
ulations typically have better insurance coverage and 
generally more free time to take care of their health needs 
[43]. When considering age as a demographic factor, we 
have found that it increases the odds of being screened, 
echoing other studies that show that adherence to CRC 
screening increases with age [44].
In terms of bereavement and stress related to death of 
family members, spouses, and friends, we had two ini -
tial hypotheses. One suggested that stress from these 
events would reduce the incentives to screening, while 
the other suggested that witnessing somebody’s death 
could incline a person to take care of their health in the 
face of the risk of possible mortality. For example, death 
of a family member from cancer could signal to a patient 
that they might have an increased risk. Our study seems 
to differentially confirm both hypotheses. Death of a 
spouse seemed to have a detrimental effect (although 
this effect was low), while death of other close people and 
pets had a positive impact (with slightly higher statistical 
significance).
Marital separation had a significant negative impact on 
adherence to cancer screening, in line with other stud -
ies that showed that marital dissolution leads to worse

Page 8 of 10
Scherbakov et al. BMC Public Health            (2025) 25:12 
health outcomes [17]. However, the effect of divorce was 
not pronounced in our sample.
Regarding demographics, we have found that Black/
African American patients in the MUSC network have 
greater odds of screening. A similar effect was observed 
for mammogram screening adherence in the same 
area [ 8]. The MUSC network might not be representa -
tive of the general population, but the same finding was 
reported by at least one more study in Pennsylvania [ 42]. 
At the same time, this comes at odds with nationwide 
research that shows racial and ethnic minorities, includ -
ing African Americans, are less likely to receive CRC 
screening compared to non-Hispanic Whites [ 45]. One 
more study indicated that there are variations in adher -
ence to screening tests based on race and ethnicity, with 
white participants showing a preference for colonoscopy, 
while non-white participants tend to prefer fecal testing 
[46]. This preference difference highlights the importance 
of considering cultural factors and individual preferences 
when promoting screening adherence among diverse 
populations.
Women had higher adherence to cancer screening in 
our population. Ritvo et al. [ 47] highlighted that women 
showed a higher rate of participation in CRC screening 
compared to men in several studies, although factors 
such as the type of screening test, participant risk group, 
and age could influence this trend. Moreover, higher edu-
cational attainment is associated with increased adher -
ence to cervical and CRC screening [ 39], suggesting that 
educational level may play a role in screening compliance 
among women.
Future work should include an expanded list of stress -
ful life events by including a validated scale of stressful 
life events for patients from historically marginalized 
groups. Current EHR systems typically lack features for 
systematic representation and screening for stressful life 
events [48]; however, we anticipate that standards-setting 
initiatives such as United States Core Data for Interoper -
ability (USCDI) and the Gravity Project initiative [ 49, 50] 
may address these gaps. Studies have shown that inter -
ventions, such as patient navigation aimed at increas -
ing adherence to CRC screening, can be effective [ 51]. 
A more systematic and structured assessment of stress -
ful life events may increase the range of interventions for 
people following stressful life events.
At the same time, it is worth noting that no list of 
stressful life events is complete. Furthermore, stressors 
are subjective and have a large interindividual variabil -
ity. Future work can explore how some factors can act as 
protectors against stressful life events, which in turn can 
promote cancer screening adherence.
Limitations
We would like to note several important limitations. 
First, we had only a small span of data available cover -
ing 10 years, with most patients having a shorter span 
of data. That implies that some patients who we marked 
as non-screened were actually screened, but we did not 
have data indicating who these patients were. Second, we 
only extracted the year of the event, not the precise date, 
and the year for “recent” events was replaced with the 
year current to the note. The effects of our analysis might 
be influenced by this factor. However, we think that our 
approach is still valid in determining the direction of 
impact and magnitude of life events.
We also omitted some stressful life events found in 
Holmes and Rahe scale by focusing on events with the 
highest mean score of impact (M > 40), only adding a 
handful of other events with a lower impact score, such 
as death of a close friend or losing financial support. 
Holmes and Rahe scale lists this latter event as “Major 
change in financial state, ” which can also include financial 
gains, which we did not consider in our study. However, 
we think that concentrating on the most impactful events 
is justifiable to make an LLM-based extraction more 
accurate.
Because analyzed events are rare and underreported 
in health records, it was not feasible to perform an ini -
tial power analysis. For this reason, we decided to use 
all the notes available to us. While we agree that we 
probably missed some of the events, especially since we 
took the pragmatic approach to reduce computational 
requirements for LLMs by using regular expressions to 
pre-screen the notes prior to LLM inference, we estimate 
recall (Table  1) and show that the recall was relatively 
high for most events in the analysis.
In our study, we used EHR data from only one institu -
tion, and some statistical associations were weak because 
of a small number of detected events; thus, further work 
is needed to validate these models at other institutions 
and, preferably, other regions of the country. Our analysis 
did not include important covariates, such as socioeco -
nomic status. It is well known that resources can buffer 
the negative effects of stress [ 52]. This information is not 
routinely collected during the patient admission process 
and is usually not reflected in free-text notes, perhaps a 
proxy variable for socioeconomic status could be the type 
of insurance used or social vulnerability based on geo -
coded addresses.
Conclusion
Adherence to CRC screening recommendations is crucial 
for early detection and prevention of the disease. Stress -
ful life events, as a unique and often invisible category in 
social determinants, play a significant role in screening 
adherence. Further exploration of protective factors and 
Page 9 of 10
Scherbakov et al. BMC Public Health            (2025) 25:12 
tailoring clinical intervention for patients who experience 
recent stressful and traumatic events is needed and could 
reduce disparities in cancer mortality.
